lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can revise the impersonal subject “it” and recognise its usage in weather and date sentences.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write example sentences using “It’s…” (e.g., It’s sunny. It’s the 3rd of May.). Students identify the subject and practise making their own.
stretchStrategies: Students write and present a “Class Weather Report” combining date + weather. Groups take turns presenting their report as if on TV.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write full sentences using “It”, weather vocabulary, and dates.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Provide sentence starters: “It’s ___ in ___.” “It’s the ___ of ___.” Students write their own two-sentence mini weather report.
stretchStrategies: Students write and present a “Class Weather Report” combining date + weather. Groups take turns presenting their report as if on TV.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can pronounce words with the “-ie”, “-y”, and “-igh” patterns correctly.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Dictate: “tie, fly, light.” Students repeat and write the correct spelling. Then practise spelling with a partner.
stretchStrategies: Students write and present a “Class Weather Report” combining date + weather. Groups take turns presenting their report as if on TV.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
